column1: Will France grant the China Global Television Network (CGTN) a license to broadcast in France before 1 January 2022?
column6: ['Business', 'Foreign Policy', 'Non-US Politics']

Interesting, how words complicate this matter: DW reported on 06 March 2021, that CGTN received "permission" by the French CSA (with the consequence of being received e.g. in the German Vodafone network), in line with the "1989 transfrontier television agreement". However, DW delivers the same interpretation that "CGTN's managers approached the Conseil Supérieur de l'Audiovisuel (CSA) for confirmation that this service was now under French jurisdiction under European law," the CSA said in a statement published on its website." and further: "a distribution license in one European country is valid across the continent, German media authorities had to notify television networks, such as Vodafone, that the CGTN channel no longer had permission to broadcast."

In my perspective CGTN was already in France. And i think, the CSA confirm this perspective. I am perplex. If CGTN did not have to seek a license to France, France will never grant a license. So from 100% of CGTN can be broadcast in France, i should answer 0% from getting a formal approval from France. https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_des_cha%C3%AEnes_de_t%C3%A9l%C3%A9vision_en_France https://www.csa.fr/Informer/Espace-presse/Communiques-de-presse/La-chaine-CGTN-releve-pour-sa-diffusion-en-Europe-de-la-competence-de-la-France https://francais.cgtn.com/channel
As the EU increasingly looks towards China for investment, member states will have to be more open to certain requests from China.
News broke they approved it. Regardless of the news, I would have still put 100% likely chance France would have approved it. https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/4141731
I think this question is kind of underspecified. @SE_Meyer notes there is cable and satellite broadcasting. And license could mean mere permission or some formal official document.

Well. I’m not going spout a conspiracy theory but I can think of something dreadfully evil that could transpire if this happens. Of course at the end of the day what will the optics look like. A twist and turn nobody would expect.
Updating because of the announcement posted by @Jean-luc-Nadeau
As i read it, It's already decide: https://www.csa.fr/Informer/Espace-presse/Communiques-de-presse/La-chaine-CGTN-releve-pour-sa-diffusion-en-Europe-de-la-competence-de-la-France

France does not want CGTN going on the air telling Islam jokes, bashing France, influencing politics etc etc etc. unless they register as a tabloid. What is objective information reporting? How do you report without bias. Some nations perhaps even France want bias in reporting.

France is seeking a stealth way to show the UK that they are welcome to cooperating despite leaving the EU. This hidden factor will play a silent yet gradually significant part in France,s decision. That's why 52 percent seats right.
Different nations have different laws regarding freedom of speech. Maybe that’s the issue.
CGTN is already in France. So there is no political or content issues.
China already dominates the world
I don't think so.

Let’s set aside nations for a minute. Just about any nation can broadcast from space. Is it possible broadcast licenses will be obsolete one day because technology bypasses the understanding of government processes? Unless of course satellites start falling out of the sky.

France has no law that prohibits state-controlled broadcasters from airing within the country. The French media watchdog, Conseil supérieur de l’audiovisuel (CSA), has stated that further analysis is required for a decision and that id would depend on technical issues rather political ones. After rejection by OFCOM in the UK of the CGTN broadcast licence, China would benefit from a positive judgement form the CSA as according to the Council of Europe Treaty, if any one member allows it broadcast, then it broadcast to all members. (The Council of Europe has 47 members that include France, UK and China). Brexit does not affect this. Therefore, CGTN could overcome the OFCOM rejection as being an arm of the Chinese Communist Party lacking editorial independence (that contravenes UK Law), but local operators would have to agree to carry the broadcaster. (Vodaphone in Germany has dropped CGTN from its cable network.) No matter the outcome, CGTN is still able to stream its content online and keep its European HQ.
Domains of warfare. What’s left?
